MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - National Day of Commemoration.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach who will be invited to participate in the National Day of Commemoration, who will issue the invitations to participants; if he will give all other relevant details; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I refer the Deputy to the reply which I gave to a similar question on 30 October 1985. The All-Party Oireachtas Committee decided that details as to who should be officially invited to participate or attend at the ceremonies and of the protocol involved were matters for the Departments and authorities concerned with the organisation of State ceremonies.

MainHeading.P: An interdepartmental committee, under the aegis of my Department, has been established to draw up detailed proposals for the implementation of the National Day ceremonies. This committee will also make recommendations on the issue of invitations to participants and other details of the ceremonies.
When the recommendations of the interdepartmental committee are available I will arrange to have them considered by the parties in this House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: Can the Taoiseach give us any indication as to when these details will be made available and, when they are made available, can he assure the House that they will be made available to the members of the committee?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I could not say when they will be available at present but certainly it will be in good time for full consideration to be given to the arrangements in advance of next July. As regards to whom they will be given, that is a matter on which I will consult with the parties. I would be perfectly happy that they should be given to members of the committee, to the Leaders of the parties, or whatever arrangement is most convenient to the Opposition.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: Can the Taoiseach give any idea of what the arrangements will be and with whom he will be consulting?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The committee will recommend certain procedures. When we have those recommendations I will then initiate consultations with the Opposition through whatever channels the Opposition feel are most appropriate for that purpose.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: In view of the fact that an inter-departmental committee has been set up, can the Taoiseach confirm whether or not it was a Government decision that members of the Government and senior members of the Army should attend last Sunday's Poppy Day ceremonies?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That seems to be a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: It is a very relevant one.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Ceist 2.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: I should point out that the question I put down initially was to the Minister for Defence. It was transferred to the Taoiseach. I am now asking the Taoiseach if he can confirm whether or not it was a Government decision that Government Ministers and senior Army officers should attend last Sunday's Poppy Day ceremonies?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: If I might answer that——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: No, the Chair feels that that is a separate question and I am ruling it out.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Central Bank Report

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if, in the light of statements in the Central Bank Report that the current budget deficit will exceed 8 per cent of GNP in 1985, the highest ever experienced, that growth in GNP is now forecast to be only 1 per cent this year, and that as a result of a larger decline then previously forecast in employment in industry and further declines in employment in the building sector and in the Public Service, an overall fall in non-agricultural employment is forecast, he still maintains that Ireland is one of the healthy economies in Europe and that a turning point in employment and living standards has been reached.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The Deputy has been careful to quote selectively from the Central Bank Report. In the very first paragraph in the report the bank states that it is encouraging to note that with some exception, stability is being restored to many areas of the economy. The Central Bank Report goes on to note the improvements which have taken place in inflation, in the current balance of payments deficit and in interest rates.

I have dealt with these matters fully in my reply to the Deputy on 23 October. On that occasion I also dealt with the question of the Exchequer finances which the bank notes is the major exception in the trend towards stability. I need hardly elaborate again on the reasons why there is such an intractable problem in this area.

It is clear from the evidence now emerging in relation to unemployment, where the rate of increase has slowed considerably, and in relation to personal consumer expenditure where the slide in retail sales which had been going on since 1980 has been reversed in recent months, that a turning point has been reached.

Recent EEC estimates indicate that in terms of GDP Ireland had a higher growth rate than any other country in the EEC in 1984. For 1985, the EEC are forecasting a GDP growth rate for Ireland which is higher than the Community average and ahead of all other member countries except the United Kingdom and Italy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: It is very difficult to have any sense of reality in dealing with this matter with the Taoiseach. First of all, may I ask him if he would agree that the current budget deficit this year will be either £1,300 million or £1,350 million, or perhaps even more, and that this will be — both in volume terms and as a percentage of GNP — the greatest single current budget deficit ever recorded in this country? Lest he thinks I am alone in this view would he refer, in replying, to the statement in the Central Bank Report to the effect that the position now is that the current budget deficit will exceed 8 per cent of GNP in 1985, the highest ever experienced? Would the Taoiseach give me his view, if he does not agree that it will be somewhere between £1,300 million and £1,350 million, as to what it will be in amount and as a percentage of GNP?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The current budget deficit this year, in so far as it is possible to estimate it at this stage with what is always a certain margin of error, will, we expect, exceed 8 per cent of GNP and, therefore, be of the order of magnitude of £1,300 million, possibly somewhat less, possibly fractionally above, as best as we can estimate at present. The figure is higher than in any other year recorded. It is two-fifths lower than the figure in 1982 that would have occurred had we not taken drastic action in the budget of 1981 and January 1982.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Order.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: We have since held it around or close to the level to which we brought it down. Total borrowing has similarly been reduced to two-fifths below the level it was likely to be at had we not taken the action we took in 1981 and 1982.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lyons Mr. Lyons
Speaker.P: Promise of government.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Leaving aside all the little fairytales which the Taoiseach has the habit the bringing into this matter, the fact is that the Taoiseach now admits to me across the House that the current budget deficit this year, after three years of his Government, will be the highest ever recorded both in volume terms and as a percentage of GNP. Would he also agree with me that, by the end of this year, the national debt will be well over £20 billion as against £12.8 billion when he came into office at the end of 1982 and that this represents the highest ever amount of borrowing by any Government in this country in their periods in office? Would the Taoiseach simply acknowledge that fact and then we shall be able to get somewhere?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I am not quite sure where the Deputy intends to get. The facts are that the level of borrowing, although significantly reduced as a share of GNP, nonetheless remains high. The facts are that the increase in the volume of public spending of 38 per cent between 1977 and 1981 pre-empted the resources available, at present growth rates, for 15 years ahead. Unless we can accelerate growth rate significantly it would take 15 years to undo the damage done by Fianna Fáil during that time——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lyons Mr. Lyons
Speaker.P: It would take a change of Government.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: ——and to get borrowing and taxation as a share of GNP down to the levels they were at in 1977 when we left office, in which year the level of foreign borrowing was actually reduced.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach has now acknowledged by not contradicting and by implicit agreement that the total national debt is now well over £20 billion as against £12.8 billion when he took office and that this represents — no matter what fairy tales he may build around it — the greatest single amount borrowed by any Government in the history of the State. Will the Taoiseach refer to the statement in the Central Bank report, which I mentioned in my question, in regard to employment? Does he accept the statement in the Central Bank report to the effect that with further declines in employment in the building sector and in the public service, offset by some improvement in private service employment, an overall fall in non-agricultural employment is forecast? Given a continuation of the long decline in numbers at work in the agricultural sector, a further increase in the labour force and a rise in the unemployment rate of around 17½ per cent on average for the year as a whole in prospect, does he agree that in the view of the Central Bank — and he can run around the world looking for other quotations if he wishes — there will be an overall fall in non-agricultural employment this year? Answer yes or no, do not waffle.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: That could be the case. It is not possible at this stage to forecast it precisely. The rate of increase in unemployment in the last 12 months at 13,300 is two thirds lower than the level at which the Deputy left it——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lyons Mr. Lyons
Speaker.P: The figures are there.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: We have gone two thirds of the way towards halting that increase which started when he was in office. Does the Deputy think he is advancing his cause by reminding the people of the damage done in those four years and the length of time it will take to catch up?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: I do not think he is doing himself any good.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: A final supplementary, please.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: It will not be the final supplementary. This is a very important question by the Leader of the Opposition to the Taoiseach on the condition of our economy, finances and unemployment. It is worth a little investigation.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: There will be other opportunities to discuss this matter. We cannot debate the economy at Question Time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: In view of the fact that the Taoiseach had the audacity to tell us last July that this is one of the healthiest economies in Europe——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy must confine himself to a question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Does the Taoiseach agree that the level of industrial employment as a whole is expected to show a larger decline this year than anyone forecast? In view of the fact that three years into the Taoiseach's administration we have the highest ever current budget deficit — by the end of this year the Government will have borrowed more money than any other Government in the history of the State — and employment will decline, does the Taoiseach agree that those three elements alone make total nonsense of his frequent statements that there is light at the end of the tunnel, that a turnaround is coming——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is argument, it is not a question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach said that we are one of the healthiest economies in Europe but, if he wishes to retain any credibility, will he please acknowledge the basic fact that his total economic and fiscal policies are a shambles?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is argument.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: The Deputy purported to quote from something I said in the Dáil. Did he check what I said?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: I did and I have it here.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: Good, so have I and I will read it out. I said:
This is now one of the healthy economies in Europe in financial terms with a growth rate higher than anybody else.

That has been proved correct. I also said that we had an inflation rate which I believed was the fourth lowest in Europe. That is what I said in respect of those two matters. They are correct and the Deputy cannot contest them. He should stop misquoting me and deal with facts although they may be unpalatable. There has been a reduction in interest rates and inflation and the level of borrowing today is two fifths lower than the figure which we were faced with in 1981. I know the Deputy will not face these facts but it will take a very long time to get borrowing back to the level at which it was when he left office in June 1981——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: That is three years ago.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: That can only be achieved by cutting expenditure or increasing growth and we are choosing the latter path. By doing that we can shorten the period of 15 years and get the economy back on course. It was in a healthy state, as your predecessor described it, in the debate in December 1977.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: This is the final supplementary.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach has talked about quotations and I should like to direct your attention to the quotation which he just made from the Official Report. He said on 11 July — and it is difficult to believe that he said it — that this is now one of the healthiest ecomomies in Europe. The Official Report strangely records that the Taoiseach said that this is now one of the healthy economies of Europe which is a bit different from what most of us recall the Taoiseach saying at the time. There must have been incredulity among economists when he said this but I physically heard him say it. After three years of the Taoiseach's administration does he not admit that the facts which I have given are incontrovertible and that the fiscal targets and economic policies which he set out are now in total ruin? Can he offer any suggestions to the House as to how he will repair the catastrophic state of public finances, the level of borrowing and the current budget? I also want to ask the Taoiseach if the IMF wolf is at the door. He will know what I mean.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach Garret FitzGerald
Speaker.P: That wolf was at the door on 30 June 1981 when I took over. We got him away from the door and we have kept him away since then. He will be kept away as long as the Government are in office and as long as the party opposite do not return to office. I repeat that what we achieved last year was the joint highest growth rate in Europe starting from a position of financial chaos four years ago. The Deputy is not willing to face that. Our inflation rate is lower than that of our neighbour; interest rates are lower than those of our neighbour for the first time in history and we have a basis for development and growth. Only through the acceleration of growth can we have any hope of getting back to the levels of taxation and borrowing of 1977. It is because of the 38 per cent increase in the volume of public spending which he and his predecessor in those disastrous years imposed on the country that we are in our present position.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am calling Question No. 3.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Haughey Mr. Haughey
Speaker.P: Does the Taoiseach not recall that the level of borrowing engaged in by the Coalition Government in 1973 to 1977 started the present trends in our public finances?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I have called Question No. 3

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Net Emigration.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach the total net emigration in the latest available year; and the corresponding annual figure assumed in the Government's economic plan.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. Barrett, Dún Laoghaire) Nuala Fennell
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Taoiseach (Mr. Barrett,
Speaker.P: Dún Laoghaire): The only reliable estimates for migration flows are those for net migration, that is the difference between the inward and outward flows betweeen successive censuses of population. These estimates are obtained by relating the intercensal population changes to date for births and deaths in the same period. For the post 1981 period, which was the most recent census year, very tentative estimates only of net migration can be made until the results of the 1986 census of population become available. These estimates of net migration are based on provisional mid-April population estimates which in turn are subject to revision in the light of the census results.

MainHeading.P: The provisional mid-April 1985 population estimate is 3,552,000 which is 109,000 above the 1981 census figure of 3,443,000. The natural increase in the population, that is, the excess of births over deaths in the same period was 141,000. thus for the four years April 1981 to April 1985 it is estimated that there was a net migration outwards of 32,000 persons which is an average of 8,000 per year. As I stated earlier, a firm estimate for the five-year period 1981 to 1986 will be available after the 1986 census.

The migration assumption underlying the labour force projection made in the plan Building on Reality was based on a special study prepared by a group of demographic experts, including experts from outside the Civil Service. The results of this work were published in April 1985 in a report entitled Population and Labour Force Projections 1986-1991. The group made assumptions about future trends in key demographic variables including migration. With respect to migration, the assumption was that over the period 1981-86 new outward migration would be in the range 5,000 to 10,000 per annum and in the period 1986-91 in the range 7,500 to 15,000 per annum. The assumption in the plan is consistent with lower limits of the range.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: Is the Minister of State aware that the latest estimate from the Central Statistics Office is a figure of 14,000 people emigrating? As he has pointed out, the figure in the national plan is 5,000 to 10,000. In view of that, will the Minister of State not agree that the figure in the national plan is a gross underestimate of the true situation?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): I do not understand the Deputy's question with regard to the national plan. If the Government were dishonest they would have taken the highest figure because it would have suited the other figures in the plan. In fact, the Government were more than honest in taking the lowest figure which made it more difficult for them in terms of projections for employment and so on.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lyons Mr. Lyons
Speaker.P: This is a new one.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): The figures in the national plan are consistent with the figures produced by the expert study group. I do not accept that the Government were wrong in their assumption in the national plan. The figures with regard to net migration are as stated. I repeat the only way we can get a firm figure is to await the outcome of the 1986 census. I am quite satisfied that the Central Statistics Office do everything in their power to get as accurate an estimate as is possible, but I admit it is not possible to be positive about the figure quoted. It is as near as can be assessed given the circumstances.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: After this supplementary we must move to the questions to the Minister for the Gaeltacht. I will allow Deputy Brennan a short supplementary question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: Is the Minister of State now aware that the Central Statistics Office estimate is 14,000 while the figure in the national plan is 5,000 to 10,000? Further, is he not aware that the labour force survey estimates in respect of outflows from 1986 to 1991 are 15,000 per annum? Is the Minister of State not aware of those official statistics which are on the record? Therefore, the figures in the national plan and which underlie the whole plan are grossly underestimated.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): The Deputy appears to be worried about the figures in the national plan. It would improve the situation for the Government if there was a higher emigration figure than what is quoted——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: How does a higher emigration figure improve the situation?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire) Mr. Barrett (Dún Laoghaire)
Speaker.P: (Dún Laoghaire): The Government took a figure of 7,000 to 7,500. The Deputy is saying now that because it is 15,000 we are worse off. That is not the case. The Deputy is saying that the estimate for this year is 14,000. He can pick whatever figure he likes. I am saying that the figures I have produced here are a fair estimate of the net migration figure. I do not accept that the Deputy should pick just one year and say that everything else is out of line.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: Nearly twice as many people are emigrating.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: In fairness I must now move to the questions addressed to the Minister for the Gaeltacht. Níl ach 17 nóiméad againn do cheisteanna d'Aire na Gaeltachta.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Seirbhísí Farantóireachta sna n-Oileáin.
MainHeading.P: 4. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta céard iad na hoileáin Ghaeltachta a bhfuil seirbhísí farantóireachta curtha ar fáil dóibh, céard é costas na seirbhísí sin agus céard atá leagtha amach ag an Aire le teacht i gcabhair ar na hoileáin nach bhfuil aon seirbhísí farantóireachta acu.

Speaker.hpid: Aire na Gaeltachta (Mr. O'Toole) Aire na Gaeltachta (Mr. O'Toole)
Speaker.P: Cuirtear seirbhís farantóireachta báid ar fáil le cabhair Stáit sna cásanna seo a leanas:
(1) Cléire — á reachtáil ag Coiste le cabhair airgid ó Roinn na Gaeltachta (deontas suas le £20,000 ceadaithe don bhliain seo móide iasacht speisialta £10,000).
(2) Árainn Mhór — á reachtáil ag Comharchumann Árainn Mhór Teo le cabhair airgid ó Údarás na Gaeltachta (timpeall £20,000 sa bhliain)
(3) Oileáin Árann — á reachtáil ag Córas Iompair Éireann

MainHeading.P: Sheas Roinn na Gaeltachta costas iomlán (£320,000) an bháid i gCléire agus sheas Udarás na Gaeltachta costas iomlán (£214,000) an bháid in Árainn Mhór. Cuireann Aer Árann Teo seirbhís rialta eitleáin go hOileáin Árann ar fáil le cabhair ó Údarás na Gaeltachta (£122,633 i 1984) agus cuireadh seirbhís thrialach héileacaptair chuig Toraigh ar fáil Feabhra-Márta i mbliana le cabhair ó Údarás na Gaeltachta (£4,755). Bíonn socruithe ar leith i bhfeidhm ar ndóigh ag An Post i ndáil le seachadadh litreacha etc chuig oileáin.

Comhairlítear dom go mbainfeadh costas de bhreis ar £1.5m le saoráidí calaíochta sásúla a fhorbairt i dToraigh a d'fhreastalódh ar sheirbhís farantóireachta don oileán sin agus nil caiteachas mar sin beartaithe faoi láthair.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An raibh aon teagmháil ag an Aire le Comhdháil na nOileán atá ag iarraidh cúrsaí a fheabhsú do mhuintir na n-oileán le áiseanna farantóireachta i gcoitinne a chur ar fáil?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Bhuail mé le muintir Chomhairle na n-Oileán ar ocáid amháin agus d'éist mé leo. Bhí a lán le plé acu agus chuir siad a lán ceisteanna orm. Glacaim leis nach bhfuil áis farantóireachta sásúil ar fud na n-oileán ar fad. B'fhearr liomsa go mór dá bhféadfáí feabhas a chur ar an scéal ach tá dul chun cinn mór déanta idir báid, eitleáin agus héileacaptair agus dé réir mar a thagann airgead breise chugainn béimid ábalta tuilleadh feabhais a chur ar na saoráidí sin.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An bhfuil aon phlean leagtha amach i gcóir gach oileán i gcaoi go mbeadh a fhios ag daoine i gceann trí bliana, cúig bliana nó deich mbliana céard tá in ann dóibh ó thaobh cúrsaí farantóireachta de — is é sin na hoileáin nach bhfuil — an áis seo curtha ar fáil dóibh go fóill?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Mar atá a fhios ag an Teachta, tá an Roinn i gcónaí ag breathnú ar céard tá ag tarlú agus céard iad na háiseanna a bheadh ag teastáil amach anseo; ach níl aon phlean sonnrach maidir le chuile oileán.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Níl ach 10 nóiméad nó mar sin fágtha againn.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: Nach bhfuilimid sásta dul ar aghaidh leis na ceisteanna i dtaobh an Ghaeltacht, má aontaíonn na Teachtaí leis?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Ní féidir linn é sin a dhéanamh do réir oird.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: An bhfuil sé ar intinn ag an Aire córas farantóireachta nua a chur ar fáil do Oileán Árainn? Tá sé seo á phlé ag an Rialtas le trí bliana anuas.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Is ceist í do CIE. Tá siad ag plé na ceiste seo agus is iad atá freagarthach as farantóireacht agus áis a chur ar fáil.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: Cen fáth an mhoill?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Dúramar leo go gcaithfeadh siad feabhas a chur ar na háiseanna, agus tá siad ag breathnú air faoi láthair.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: Tá sé á phlé ag an Rialtas ar feadh trí bliana anois.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Is iad CIE atá freagarthach as.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An nglacfaidh an tAire i leith seirbhís farantóireachta d'Arann Mhór go bhfuil gá go gcuirfí leis an falla atá ansin? Tá cupla míle punt ag teastáil uainn chun an falla ansin a leathnú.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Táimid ag breathnú air faoi láthair. Níl mé cinnte go baileach céard atá ag teastáil ansin le go bhféadfaí feabhas a chur ar an áis. Má chuireann an Teachta ceist orm faoi amach anseo beidh mé in ann níos mó eolais a thabhairt dó faoi.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Caiteachas ar Bhóthar Mhúscraí.
MainHeading.P: 5. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Moynihan Mr. D. Moynihan
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta cé mhéid airgid atá beartaithe aige a chaitheamh ar an bpríomh bhóthar trí Ghaeltacht Mhúscraí i 1986.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Os cúnamh ar mhaithe le bóithre áise a chuireann mo Roinnse ar fáil as an soláthar teoranta airgid a bhíonn ar fáil di ní fhéadfaí cabhair a thabhairt don bhóthar atá i gceist ag an Teachta.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Moynihan Mr. D. Moynihan
Speaker.P: An mbeidh aon airgead le haghaidh na hoibre seo i mbliana?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Ní bóthar áise é ach bóthar chontae. Go deimhin, is bóthair chontae ar fad atá ag dul trí Mhúscraí.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Aerstráicí Oileáin Árainn.
MainHeading.P: 6. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta cathain a thosófar obair ar rúidbhealaí nua a chur ar fáil ar Inis Mór, Inis Meáin agus Inis Oírr, Contae na Gaillimhe agus cathain a thógfar soillse tuirlingte.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Maidir le dromchlaí crua do na haerstráicí ar Oileáin Árainn tuigim ó Údarás na Gaeltachta gur mar seo a leanas atá:
Inis Mór agus Inis Meáin: Ach deacrachtaí teidil a bheith réitithe meastar go dtosófar ar an obair go luath san athbhliain.
Inis Oírr: Ach deacrachtaí teidil a bheith réitithe meastar go dtosófar ar an obair i rith na bliana seo chugainn.

Tuigim freisin ón Údarás nach bhféadfaí ach feidhm an-teoranta a bhain as soilse tuirlingthe ar na haerstráicí ar na hoileáin go dtí go mbeadh soilse ar an aerfort mórthíre óna mbíonn an aersheirbhís. Coimeádfar an cheist faoi bhreithniú.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: An bhfuil sé i gceist na soilse a chur ar Charn Mór cosúil leis na haerphoirt ar an morthír?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Níl mé cinnte faoí sin.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: An n-aontaíonn an tAire gur ceist phráinneach í seo mar nach bhfuil aon tseirbhís sábhailte ar fáil sna hoileáin san oíche? Fiú amháin an tseachtain seo caite chualamar faoí na daoine a gortaíodh i nDún na nGall. Bhí orthu fanacht ar feadh ocht n-uaire a chloig sula rabhadar in ann na daoine a iompar go dtí an t-ospidéal, cuid acu gortaithe go dona. Caithfidh an tAire admháil nach bhfuil sé sin sásuil. Dá gcuirfí soilse ar fáil i gCam Mór agus ag an aerstráice in Arainn bheadh an tseirbhís ina seirbhís sábháilte sna hoileáin ar feadh 20 uair sa ló.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tá mé cinnte go n-aontódh an Teachta liom, go dtí go mbeidh na soilsí ar fáil sa Charn Mór beidh teora leis an úsáid a bhféadfaí a bhaint as na soilsí ar na hoileáin. Chomh fada agus is eol dom tá sé ar intinn soilsí a chur ar Charn Mór, agus ag an bpointe sin beimid in ann breathnú ar cheist na h-áise céanna a sholáthar do na hoileáin.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: An bhfuil sé ar intinn ag an Aire aerstráicí nua a chur sna trí oileáin. Dúirt sé go dtosnófaí iad go léir an bhliain seo chugainn?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Inis Mór, tá £80,000 i gceist; Inis Meáin, £80,000; agus Inis Oírr £186,000.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: An bhfuil an tAire ag rá go gcríochnófar an obair ar fad sin an bhliain seo chugainn?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Dá mbeadh ceisteanna teidil socraithe: tá ceist Inis Mór beagnach socraithe agus beidh sé ag tosnú go luath. In Inis Oírr tá suas le 65 tionóntaí i gceist ach ní dóigh liom go mbeidh morán deacrachta leis agus beidh sé in ann tosnú san athbhliain.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Údarás na Gaeltachta.
MainHeading.P: 7. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta cén cinneadh atá tugtha aige ar an scrúdú a bhí ar siúl aige ar fheidhmeanna agus ar obair Údarás na Gaeltachta.

MainHeading.P: 8. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta cén fáth gur cuireadh siar ainmniú chathaoirleach agus bhaill Údarás na Gaeltachta le haghaidh an lántéarma 1985-1990.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tógfaidh mé Ceisteanna 7 agus 8 le chéile.

Amhail mar a d'fhógair mé nuair a bhí ceapacháin á ndéanamh agam le héifeacht ó 1 Aibreán 1985 is ceapacháin go dtí 31 Nollaig 1985 atá i gceist ó tharla scrúdú a bheith á dhéanamh agam ar fheidhmeanna agus ar obair Údarás na Gaeltachta. Tá an scrúdú sin ar siúl go fóill.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An bhfuil sé i gceist an cumhacht atá ag na daoine ata tofa ag muintir na Gaeltachta a bhaint dóibh agus nach mbeidh siad ag plé feasta le obair an Údáráis ach le cúrsaí soisialta, nach mbeidh baint ar bith acu le cúrsaí forbartha ná cúrsaí eacnamaíochta a bhaineann le forbairt na Gaeltachta.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Mar adúirt mé cheana sa Teach seo, tá scrúdú á dhéanamh ag Comhchoiste an Oireachtais ar an Údarás nach bhfuil críochnaithe go fóill. Tá scrúdú déanta ag Roinn na Seirbhíse Poiblí. Tá an tuarascáil sin ag na comhaltaí agus agamsa agus tá scrúdú de mo chuid féin á dhéanamh agam. Ó na trí cinn agam beidh me in ann a dhéanamh amach céard is fearr a dhéanamh. Níl tada socraithe go fóill.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An n-inseoidh an tAire dúinn cad chuige ar chuir sé an fiosrúchán seo ar siúl? An é nach bhfuil muinín aige as na baill tofa atá in Údarás na Gaeltachta?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Ni mise a chuir scrúdú Chomhchoiste an Oireachtais ar siúl, ach an Teach seo. Ni raibh tada le déanamh agamsa leis. Maidir leis an fiosruchán a bhí á dhéanamh ag Roinn na Seirbhíse Poiblí——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: Tá an tAire mar bhall den Rialtas.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Is é an Teach seo a chuir ar Chomhchoiste an Oireachtais an rud seo a dhéanamh. Maidir leis an scrúdú a rinne Roinn na Seirbhíse Poiblí, is é an Rialtas a rinne an moladh sin. Rinneadh é sin ina lán cásanna eile chomh maith. Níor piocadh an tÚdarás amach go speisialta.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - An Deontas £10.
MainHeading.P: 9. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Ormonde Dr. Ormonde
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta cén líon daltaí (a) ar ceadaíodh an deontas £10 dóibh sa scoilbhliain 1984-1985; (b) ar diúltaíodh an deontas dóibh.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Thuill 6,173 dhalta an deontas £10 agus 125 dhalta an deontas £20 don scoilbhliain 1984-85 agus diúltaíodh é i gcás 2,312 dhalta. Tá roinnt cásanna le glanadh fós.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: An bhfuil laghdú ar an líon páistí a thuilleann an deontas le blianta anuas nó an bhfuil ardú ag teacht orthu?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Nil an t-eolas sin agam ach dá gcuirfeadh an Teachta ceist orm i leith na blianta a chuaigh thart bheinn in ann an t-eolas sin a thabhairt dí.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: Nach ceart anois an deontas seo a ardú suas le £100 mar nár ardaíodh é suas le 20 bliain.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Ceist eile e sin. Cuireadh ceist orm faoin líon daoine.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: Nach bhfuil aon tuairimí ag an Aire faoin gceist a chuir mé air?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Ní aontóinn leis an Teachta gan scrúdú a dhéanamh ar an loighic a bhaineann le íocaíocht a leithéid de dheontas. Mar atá a fhios ag an Teachta tá sé fite fuaite le deontais eile agus ní féidir an deontas sin a thógáil leis féin.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: An bhfuil sé i gceist ag an Aire anois é sin a chríochnú chomh maith le deontais eile atá stopaithe aige?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Ní dúirt mé é sin agus ní ceart go dtuigfí go ndúirt mé é sin.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Deontais do Scoláirí Gaeilge.
MainHeading.P: 10. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta an bhfuil sé i gceist aige aon deontas a chur ar fáil an bhliain seo chugainn le cur ar chumas Údarás na gColáistí Samhraidh iar-chúram a sholáthar i gcaitheamh na bliana dá scoláirí idir cúrsaí.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Níl a leithéid i gceist ach bheinn ag súil go ndéanfadh údaráis na gcoláistí féin iarracht, feadh a gcumais, le hiarchúram a sholáthar do dhaltaí a bhí ar chúrsaí seo.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: An n-aontódh an tAire gurb é sin an gné den chúrsa Gaeilge is daoire ar na coláistí agus nach bhfuil go leor de údaráis na gcolaístí in acmhainn an costas a sheasamh iad féin? Sin an chéad cheist agus an dara ceist: má tá sé i gceist ag an Aire le cabhair an Aire Oideachais aon chaighdeánú a dhéanamh ar na coláistí samhraidh i dtreo go mbeadh torthaí níos fearr acu siúd nach bhfuil torthaí maith acu faoi láthair, nach gceapann an tAire go bhfuil fiorphráinn ag baint le airgead nó deontaìs de shaghas éigin a chur ar fáil do údarás na gcoláistí samhraidh chun iar-chúram a chur ar fáil.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Mar atá a fhios ag an Teachta, tá deontas á chur ar fáil do choláistí i leith na hoibre seo agus go deimhin faraor ní leor é don obair atá idir lámha acu, ach is ceist airgid é. Ní rud é a déantar de gnáth agus téann furmhór na bpáistí seo ar ais ar scoil ar aon nós agus tá an Ghaeilge á cleachtadh acu ar scoil. Ba rud a chuirfeadh le úsáid na Gaeilge agus a chuirfeadh feabhas ar léibhéal na Gaeilge agus caighdeán na Gaeilge ag na daltaí seo ach tá cuid mhaith á caitheamh ar na coláistí féin ón Roinn agus go deimhin ón Roinn Oideachais chomh maith. Ba mhaith an rud é dá mbeadh go leor airgid againn lena dhéanamh.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: An fó-cheist deireannach.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: An mbeadh an tAire sásta iarratas a bhreithniú agus deontas a chur ar fáil——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Bheinn sásta breathnú air cinnte ach ni thabharfainn aon tuairim ar céard a thiocfadh as sin?

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: I should like to draw your attention, a Cheann Comhairle to the echo coming across the House from the equipment; it is most unsatisfactory.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That will be attended to. Ní mór dúinn na ceisteanna maidir leis an Aire Iascaigh agus Foraoiseachta a thógáil anois. Ceist a 21.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: Níl mise sásta go bhfuil an t-am do cheisteanna do Aire na Gaeltachta gearrtha siar agus nach bhfuil an tam ar fad ar fáil chun na ceisteanna sin a fhreagairt. Níl me sásta leis an socrú sin.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Tá sin de réir an ordaithe a rinneadh anseo Dé Máirt. 28 Bealtaine, agus níl aon rud gur féidir liomsa a dhéanamh. Ceist 21.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Fish Imports.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lyons Mr. Lyons
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry the volume and value of fish imports in 1984 and to date in 1985; and the efforts he is making to substitute home produced fish products for these imports.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Imports of fish products, excluding fish meal in 1984 amounted to 26,476 tonnes at a value of £29.1 million. The comparable figures for the period January to August of 1985 which is the latest period for which the information is available were 17,019 tonnes and £22.1 million respectively.

MainHeading.P: An Bord Iascaigh Mhara have recently increased their promotional work on the domestic market and are undertaking a programme to encourage increased home consumption of fresh fish and to help Irish fish processors to secure a larger share of the home market particularly for fish products which can be manufactured here. Meetings with supermarkets are also being arranged by the Minister of State, at my Department, Deputy D'Arcy, with a view to encouraging them to sell more Irish processed fish products.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lyons Mr. Lyons
Speaker.P: Is it not a disgrace that a maritime nation like ours should be importing so much fish having regard to the cost of those imports and also to the very important factor of the extremely high rate of unemployment? Would he not agree also that more action should be taken by the Government through their agencies to ensure that this position is redressed? The Minister has told us that fish imports in 1984 amounted to 27,000 tonnes at a value of £29.1 million and that up to the end of August this year the value of fish products imported amounted to £22.1 million. Is the Minister satisfied that everything possible is being done and every effort made to redress this position? Will he ensure that his Department and the many State agencies concerned will set to work immediately in this regard?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: The Deputy may rest assured that I am making and will continue to make every effort with my Department to ensure that the result of the talks will be achieved. We are very backward in the fish processing area. We have been very slow to make strides in secondary processing particularly. I am talking about the preparation of fish products up to the point of cooking. That is an area that we have not been developing to the extent that I should like to see it developed. My Department can go so far and we can catch enough fish to enable us to reach the high level of development that is desired but we are talking here about private investment being prepared to invest its money. Private investors can avail of the various grants from the other agencies such as the IDA or Údarás na Gaeltachta, as the case might be. However, I cannot force people to invest in projects in which they do not wish to invest.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - State Forests.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he has had discussions with commercial interests regarding the possible sale, leasing or involvement of the private sector in the State forests.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if the Government are considering handing over to private interests any area of State forestry; if it is Government policy that areas of State forestry should be sold to private interests; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry the discussions he or officials of his Department have had on the disposal of State forestry to private banking, financial or other institutions; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 22 and 27 and Priority Question No. 54 together.

I have had no discussions with any private interests in regard to the disposal of State forests. Over the years officials of my Department have had meetings from time to time with private interests who had expressed a wish to explore the possibility of investing in the State forest enterprise but to date nothing positive has emerged from such discussions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Can the Minister clarify the confusion that has arisen as a result of statements made by the Minister for Finance in Killarney to the effect that this issue was discussed by the Government at a recent meeting at Barretstown Castle?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Some of the Deputies interventions at the time did not help to clear up the confusion.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: I did not create it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: There is no confusion. The fact is that this year in Barretstown as the Minister said, many things were discussed in relation to the economy, including the development of forestry. The selling off of State forests came up in the context of on-going discussions which were commenced in 1980 by the then Minister for Finance, Deputy Fitzgerald, and from the Deputy's time in my Department he is well aware that discussions took place which were not concluded when he left office. They are still not concluded simply because I am not satisfied that the proposals put to us from the private sector are satisfactory and that the taxpayers' interests are being looked after. The Deputy is well aware of the context in which this discussion took place. These discussions were started when he was in office, during the time of his immediate predecessor and the office holder before him.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Deputy Mac Giolla has a question down and I am calling him.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: There is further confusion——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am calling Deputy Mac Giolla.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: I have a priority question down.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: Will the Minister tell the House the names of the private interests with whom he has been having talks? What is the extent of the forestry involved in these discussions?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I repeat that I have had no discussions personally with any private interests, but my Department's officials have had discussions with different groups who have shown an interest, one of them being the group which publicly stated they had £X billion available for the purchase of State forests.
As regards the second part of the Deputy's question — what extent of the State forests are being discussed — there is no detailed discussion of that nature going on.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: Is it just the current mature forests?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: We are talking about leasing and whether private investment is available for the leasing of non-afforested areas where land could be leased and afforested by the private sector. It is not true that State forests are being sold to the private sector.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: The Minister must be aware that there are two separate issues involved. The issue about which the Minister is making accusations——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: A question, please, Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: ——relates to encouraging private individuals and private financial institutions to invest in the development of new forestry, but we want to find out about a separate issue. Are the Minister and the Government involved in discussions to sell off mature forests, or forests which are about to mature, to private financial institutions? The Minister should not try to confuse the situation further.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: The Minister and the Government are not involved in discussions on the sale of mature forests at the moment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Lyons Mr. Lyons
Speaker.P: I am glad to have that clarified.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: The Deputy's predecessor, in this House castigated the then Minister, the present Ceann Comhairle, for not taking up an offer of £10 million for the sale of mature forests.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Will the Minister give a definite yes or no? Have the Government discussed the possibility of selling off mature forests?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is repetition.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: We cannot get an answer.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is not my fault.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Does the Deputy understand “No”.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: If Deputy Seán Treacy has a short question I will allow it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Treacy Mr. S. Treacy
Speaker.P: I want to ascertain if the Minister forgot to mention that he was replying also to Question No. 50, which deals with the same subject, or will he come to Question No. 50 later?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Minister did not say he was taking it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Treacy Mr. S. Treacy
Speaker.P: I asked the Minister if he will desist from any attempt to dispose of any vestige of State forests to private interests until Dáil Éireann is consulted and decides on such a proposal; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That question has not been called. The Minister did not say he was taking it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Treacy Mr. S. Treacy
Speaker.P: Is it not strange that it was not taken with these questions?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I cannot help the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Treacy Mr. S. Treacy
Speaker.P: Will the Minister reassure us that this precious State asset will not merely be preserved but will be expanded upon by the rigorous acquisition of additional land and the provision of more jobs? Can he give the House an assurance that the livelihood of the existing employees and their pension rights will be safeguarded now and in the future?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy is asking a supplementary question on a question which has not been called.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Treacy Mr. S. Treacy
Speaker.P: It is the same subject matter.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy knows he should not persist in this.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Treacy Mr. S. Treacy
Speaker.P: I should be grateful if the Minister would give me a reply.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am calling Question No. 23.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Oyster Fishing.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he is aware that there is an urgency about dealing with an application to his Department from West Mayo Fishing Co-operative, which would enable them to control oyster fishing in the area they have specified; and if he will take steps to ensure that this licence is granted immediately.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Officials of my Department have recently been in touch with the co-operative regarding the application from the co-opertive for an aquaculture licence under section 54 of the Fisheries Act, 1980, and the co-opertive are to forward further information and documentation.
The Deputy can be assured that this matter is being dealt with as quickly as possible.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that unless action is taken fairly quickly by his Department stocks may be wiped out? Because of the urgency of the matter, the co-operative are most anxious that an early decision should be arrived at.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I can assure the Deputy that there is one small matter which has to be clarified with the co-operative and, having cleared that, I will issue a temporary licence which will cover the danger he mentioned.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: How many applications for aquaculture licences are before his Department?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: Will the Minister tell the House the reason for the delay in dealing with applications for aquaculture licences and if it is not true that there is not——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: This question deals with one item and the Deputy is broadening it. That is not fair when there is so little time left.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: The question is relevant to the delay——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: It is not relevant to this question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: The Mayo application, along with others, is being delayed because there is no full time official in the Department dealing with these licences. The matter is not getting priority. This is a national disgrace.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: This question deals only with the Mayo application. Deputy Molloy should not argue with the Chair. I am calling Question No. 24.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Forestry Area Joint Ventures.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he has any plans to undertake joint ventures in the forestry area; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: In accordance with the Government's National Plan, Building on Reality, my Department are examining the possibilities for public-private ventures to expand the rate of afforestation in Ireland but this examination has not yet reached the stage at which firm proposals can be formulated.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: When is it likely to be concluded?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: The proposals are being dealt with in detail at the moment and I expect an early conclusion to the deliberations.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - State Forests.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he has considered or evaluated the possibility of Bord na Móna taking over control and management of State forests; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: No. As the Deputy knows, I set up a representative review group last year to examine the present structure, organisation and operation of the Forest and Wildlife Service of my Department with a view to ensuring that the country's afforestation programme is developed and exploited to the best national advantage. I expect to receive the group's final report and recommendations very shortly and until these have been examined it would not be appropriate to consider what changes in the present organisation, if any, are necessary.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Is the Minister aware that he himself has circumvented the working of that committee and already the committee are in total disarray? There has been a resignation——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is not a question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: ——of a very popular member of that committee.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is not a question. It is a statement.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Does the Minister seriously believe that we will take this type of reply from him? The Minister knows the committee are in total disarray, that there is total chaos and they cannot get their final report together.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: It is not a question. Ceist 52.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I must move on to the next question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: In reply to the allegation that this committee have disbanded and are in disarray——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: There has been a resignation by one of the main members of the committee.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: If a person resigns from a committee, that is his or her business. As far as I am concerned the committee have now completed their deliberations and have signed the report.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Since when?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Last week.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Ceist 52. Táimid ag dul ar aghaidh leis na ceisteanna ar sonnraíodh uainn dóibh.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Bord Údarás na Gaeltachta.
MainHeading.P: 52. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta an bhfuil sé ar eolas aige gur fágadh na céardchumainn gan guth ar bhord Údarás na Gaeltachta nuair a chaith sé an tUasal Ó Néill amach as an mbord agus an inseoidh sé an é polasaí an Rialtais é gan aitheantas ar bith a thabhairt do na céardchumainn feasta sna ceapacháin a bheas á ndéanamh nuair a bhíonn baill do bhord Stáit á n-ainmniú.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tá míthuiscint ar an Teachta faoin sceál.

MainHeading.P: Is amhlaidh go bhfuil duine d'fhoireann an Údaráis atá ina chéardchumannaí ceaptha agam mar chomhalta den bhord. Níl aon bhunús leis an líomhain sa chuid deiridh den Cheist.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An n-aontódh an tAire go raibh gnás ann go mbeadh duine ainmnithe ó na céardchumainn mar bhaill den Údarás agus nach ndearnadh sin agus nach bhfuil sé sásúil? Aontaím gur ceart go mbeadh ball den lucht oibre ar an mbord ach nach mbeadh sé i bhfad níos sásúla dá mbeadh duine ainmnithe ag na céardchumainn mar bhall de Bhord an Údaráis agus nár dearnadh é sin?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tá oifigeach ón ASTMS ainmnithe do Bhord an Údaráis.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An bhfuil an tAire ag rá gurab shin é an gnás a bhí ann agus go bhfuil sé ag cloí leis an nós a bhí ann cheana maidir le duine a ainmniú do Bhord an Údaráis.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: No, no. Uair amhaín a tharla sé. Níl aon riail ann maidir leis sin. Agus d'ainmnigh mise duine atá ansin mar chomhalta, duine go bhfuil an-bhaint aige le obair an ASTMS agus tá na céardchumainn sásta leis an scéal.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An n-aontódh an tAire gur ceart duine ó na céardchumainn a bheith mar bhall de Bhord an Údaráis, rud nach ndearna an tAire nuair a thug sé an sac don duine a bhí ann cheana agus níor chuir sé duine ar bith ina áit?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Níor thug mé deis do na céardchumainn é a ainmniú agus, chomh fada agus is eol dom, tá na céardchumainn lán sásta leis an té a d'ainmigh mise.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: Cad mar gheall ar an Workers Participation Act a chur i bhfeidhm san Údarás?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Sin í an cheist atá á plé faoi láthair.

MainHeading.P: 53. D'fhiafraigh

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: d'Aire na Gaeltachta an bhfuair sé an t-eolas a bhí á iarraidh aige i dtaobh láimhseáil iasachtaí áirithe airgid ag iarPhríomh-Fheidhmeannach Údarás na Gaeltachta nuair a chinn sé an bóthar a thabhairt dó agus do bhaill áirithe de Bhord Údarás na Gaeltachta; agus an inseoidh sé cén uair atá sé i gceist aige an t-eolas sin a chur os comhair na Dála.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Chuir mé an t-eolas a bhí agam i dtaobh na hiasachta sin ar fáil don Dáil ar 17 Samhain 1983 (col. 2631 et seq.). Níl aon eolas breise ábharthach le tabhairt agam ina leith.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: An inseodh an tAire cad tá déanta aige ó 1983 chun an teolas sin a chur ar fáil don Dáil?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Ba mhaith liom a rá ag an bpointe seo go bhfuil litir dlíodóra fáite ag an Údarás i leith na faidhbe seo agus níor mhaith liom aon rud a rá a chuirfeadh isteach ar cibé a tharlódh amach anseo.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An n-aontódh an tAire go raibh eagóir déanta ar thriur a bhí ina mbaill de Bhord an Údaráis agus go raibh daoine ag ceapadh ag an am sin go raibh rud éigin bun os cionn le hobair an Údaráis agus le Bord an Údaráis nuair a thug sé an sac dóibh agus go raibh trí bhliain aige leis an scéal a mhiniú don Dáil agus nach bhfuil tada déanta aige leis an rud sin a chur i gceart agus leis na daoine seo a ghlanadh?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tá sé anois i lámha na ndlíodóirí agus ní ceart domsa aon rud a rá a chuirfeadh isteach ar cibé a tharlódh.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Nuair a tugadh isteach an bhreith i bhfábhar an phríomhfheidhmeannaigh ar chinntigh sé sin nach raibh aon rud mícheart san Údarás nuair a d'éirigh leis slám airgid nach bhfuil a fhios againn tada faoi, nuair a fuair sé sin ina ghlac, agus de réir cosúlachta, gur dhruid sé a bhéal chomh maith. An bhfuil an tAire a rá anois de bharr an cinnidh sin nach raibh tada micheart agus nár dearnadh rud ar bith as bealach?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tá mé ag rá go bhfuarthas litreacha ó dhlíodóiri go dlíodoírí agus nach bhfuil mise sásta mo ladhar a chur isteach ag an bpointe seo, agus bheadh an Teachta ag tabhairt amach dom dá ndéanfainn a leithéid.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: An n-aontódh an tAire go bhfuil trí bliana caite nach raibh san rud ar fad ach polaitíocht, go raibh an tAire ag iarraidh a mheon feín a shásamh agus go ndearna sé éagóir ar dhaoine nach raibh tada mícheart déanta acu.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tá mise sásta go ndearna mé an rud ceart ag an am.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Gallagher Mr. D. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Dúirt an tAire go raibh sé sásta go ndearna sé an rud ceart ag an am. An é atá i gceist aige anois nó an é atá á rá aige go raibh éagóir déanta ag na daoine seo, go raibh airgead curtha amú agus nach raibh siad ag déanamh a gcuid oibre mar bhaill den Udarás?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: Tá an Teachta ag iarraidh focail a chur i mo béal. Tá mé ag rá go bhfuil mé sasta i mo intinn féin go ndearna mé an rud ceart ag an am. Dúirt mé é sin cheana agus tá mé á rá anois arís.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - White Paper on Fishing Industry.

Speaker.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry when the White Paper on the fishing industry, which was promised in the Building on Reality, 1985-1987 document, will be published, and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry when the Government's White Paper on the fishing industry will be published; and the reason for the delay in preparing it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I propose to take Question No. 38 and Priority Question No. 55 together.
Work on the preparation of the White Paper is well advanced in my Department and my aim is to have it published before the end of this year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: The Minister will be aware that discussions have been going on for some time in relation to the White Paper and that the White Paper has been promised by the Minister for over 12 months? The Minister will also be aware that there has been another report, a report on the fishing industry which has indicated the way forward for development in the fishing industry. Can the Minister give us a broad outline of what the White Paper will contain and what he would see as priority areas to which the White Paper will direct attention.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: The Deputy is well aware that I cannot give in any detail the content of the White Paper. I can tell him that the White Paper is being expedited and at the moment it has been circulated to other Departments for their observations after which it will come back to the Government for scrutiny and the Government will make a decision.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: The Minister will be fully aware of the background and the volume of information which has been made available already of the state of preparation of the White Paper. Can we get some indication from the Minister of the main headings that the White Paper will direct attention to, whether, for instance, inland fisheries will be covered and whether there will be any reference to developments within the Community? The Minister will be aware that one matter which is causing widespread concern at present is the question of quotas and the inadequate quota arrangements we have. He will be aware of widespread dissatisfaction with the quota of herring, mackerel and hake. Can he give us some indication as to what the White Paper will say in this regard?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: The Deputy is trying to bait me now — excuse the pun. The White Paper contains proposals on inland fisheries, something which the Euro policy document did not contain to any great extent. He also can expect from me that in regard to the other agencies who did a great deal of work on the current state of the fishing industry in the past few years, the contents of their documents have been taken into consideration in formulating the White Paper on Fisheries and the White Paper at the moment is being circulated in Departments.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: We cannot discuss a White Paper at Question Time.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Can we get some indication from the Minister about the quota situation which is causing widespread anxiety——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The question clearly asks when the White Paper will be published.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: The Minister will have to take into account the present state of the industry——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is another question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: The Minister will be aware that the industry is anxious at present because of the lack of adequate quotas——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Just because it is a question about fisheries we cannot mount an argument on the entire fishery scene.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: We have to take adequate time to deal with it.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: We are not making the best use of it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: We did not get an opportunity to take some of the important questions on the Order Paper today. The Minister has time, so can be tell us what is involved and whether the White Paper will address itself to this situation?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am ruling that question out of order. I have been asked to improve Question Time and if I allow questions like this the whole thing will get worse instead of better. Deputy Pat Cope Gallagher.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: Does the Ceann Comhairle appreciate——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Sorry, Deputy, please bear with me. I was wrong in calling on Deputy Gallagher.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: We are on Question No. 54 and Question No. 38 which is not a priority question.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: When a priority question and a non-priority question are taken together in priority time only the Deputy with the question down can put a question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: I accept your ruling on the basis that there is no precedent.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: It is stated in the Order.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: I consider myself the same as Deputy Molloy in this House. Deputy Molloy asked a question on priority and I did not get the opportunity, so I say to you, a Cheann Comhairle, that you are discriminating between Deputy Molloy and me.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I am only human and I nod occasionally.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Gallagher Mr. P. Gallagher
Speaker.P: I am proposing to seek to raise it with the Committee on Procedure and Privileges.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: You will be welcome to raise it there.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: I might have asked a question, but I got no answer.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: In relation to the inland fisheries section in the White Paper can the Minister give the House an indication——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I ruled that question out of order.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Will the Minister recognise that at present there is widespread dissatisfaction with the way in which his Department are dealing with mariculture and aquaculture licences?

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I would prefer the Deputy——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: That party did not even mention it in their policy document.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: Ceist 56.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna — Questions. Oral Answers. - Review Group on Forestry.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry the reasons the Review Group on Forestry who were appointed in November 1984, and who were to report by 1 June 1985, have not yet reported; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry when the findings of the Review Group on Forestry will be published; and the reason for the undue delay in the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I propose to take Question No. 31 and Priority Question No. 56 together.

I understand that the Forestry Review Group have almost completed their work and that their report will be submitted to me in the very near future. Having regard to the complexity of the task I do not accept that there was undue delay by the group who have been meeting very frequently during the past year.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: Will the Minister confirm that prior to the final report of the review body, the individual members whom he appointed to the review body gave him a synopsis of the main recommendations and the trend of those recommendations?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I wish to point out to the Deputy that indeed I got a synopsis of the up to date position on where they stood prior to the completion by the——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Daly Mr. Daly
Speaker.P: From two individuals.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I have a right to consult with and talk to any member of any board I appoint at any time without “by your leave” from the Deputy or anybody else. I stand over that right.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: And we have a right to question the Minister about the situation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: I fail to see why that right is suggested to be something I should not exercise by people who ought to know better. I am sure that Deputy Daly in this House as Minister——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Molloy Mr. Molloy
Speaker.P: ——has had the same right to ask.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. O'Toole Mr. O'Toole
Speaker.P: ——had exactly the same right.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick

MainHeading.Title: National Development Corporation Bill, 1985: Second Stage (Resumed).
MainHeading.P: Question again proposed: “That the Bill be now read a Second Time.”

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hyland Mr. Hyland
Speaker.P: Before we adjourned for lunch I made a fairly lengthy contribution on to the National Development Corporation Bill. I accused the Government and the Minister of childish political manoeuvring for the sake of bringing before the House another Bill which has no impact and will certainly not do what it is intended to do or what has been stated it will do by the Minister in relation to job creation and industrial development. I do not think there is any real credibility in introducing a Bill simply for the sake of change. I do not mean change for the better in the economy but simply a change of wording and a formula of words which will eventually find their place in the Dáil Library.

I made the point that the NEA, set up under a Fianna Fáil Government, had stood the test of time and had done an extremely good job in relation to job creation and supporting industry. I said to the Minister before the adjournment that, instead of bringing in a Bill to establish a new layer of bureaucracy, he should have supported the NEA three years ago. If he had given them the same level of support as he is talking about in terms of this Bill, we would not have the many problems which have compounded themselves over the past three years. I made the point also——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I hope the Deputy does not intend to repeat what he said before lunch.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hyland Mr. Hyland
Speaker.P: I do not.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: It would not be in order.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hyland Mr. Hyland
Speaker.P: I will not go over the ground I covered in my earlier contribution. It is relevant and important again to establish the context in which this debate is taking place. For any legislation to be successful in the area of job creation and industry support you must in the first instance have a favourable economic climate. In the Bill the Minister is endeavouring to do one thing while his colleagues in Government by their actions are undermining any efforts he is making at job creation. Earlier I outlined five economic indicators which clearly indicate that Government policies in the area of economic development in the last three years have failed. For that reason one must be very doubtful about the proposals in the Bill.

We are not dealing with a complicated piece of legislation and there is no reason why there should have been a delay of three years before it was brought to the House. If the Minister believed that the provisions would mean a start on the task of tackling our economic problems he would have introduced the legislation earlier. I would be happy to support any move by the Minister to resolve the unemployment problem. I would support any move by him to help industrial development. The Minister believes the provisions in the Bill will deal with our economic problems and in that regard I accuse him, and the Government, of negligence in the last three years. The Bill is simple in terms of the form of words used, but finance has not been provided by the Government to implement its proposals.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: That is not true.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hyland Mr. Hyland
Speaker.P: The Minister will have an opportunity to reply to the points I am making.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Bruton Mr. J. Bruton
Speaker.P: The Deputy has repeated that particular inaccuracy six times.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hyland Mr. Hyland
Speaker.P: I can assure the Minister that I will return to the Chamber when he is replying in the hope of hearing him deal with the points I am bringing to his notice. The Minister will not succeed in putting me off my train of thought by his interruptions because I feel too strongly about these issues to be distracted in any way. If the Bill is to do what the Minister has told us, why is it that we have had to wait three years for it during which time every facet of our economy has been undermined? Had the Bill been introduced two years ago we would have been in a position to assess whether it achieved the objectives set out. I would like to think that the corporation will at least commence to tackle the problem of unemployment and industrial development but I do not think that will happen although I wish the Minister well in his efforts.

It is the duty and responsibility of the Government in the first instance to stabilise and improve the economic climate for industrial expansion. It may not be the direct responsibility of the Government to create all the new jobs, but it is their duty to create a favourable economic climate. That climate has not existed here for some time. The only sustainable jobs are those created as a result of increased production and greater wealth. It is true that we are well served by the various elements of the public sector and we all acknowledge the important role that sector has played in our economic development up to now. It is also true to say that some areas of the public sector are seriously undermanned, something which is not often mentioned in the House. That is costing the State a lot in terms of lost revenue.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy will have to relate his remarks to the Bill.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hyland Mr. Hyland
Speaker.P: My remarks relate to the Bill because the legislation is about job creation. I am stressing the need for a favourable economic climate so that the provisions in the Bill can succeed.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: That is a matter for two different debates. The Deputy can only debate the Bill in detail. He may make a passing reference to other things but this is not a suitable subject for an economic debate or even a debate on unemployment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hyland Mr. Hyland
Speaker.P: I wish to comply with the ruling of the Chair and I shall do my best to relate my remarks to the terms of the Bill. However, the Chair must agree that the Bill purports to relate to a very wide economic area as far as job creation and industrial development are concerned. It is extremely difficult to debate any legislation designed to deal with our economic problems without referring, perhaps in passing, to some economic indicators.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I have no objection to a passing reference.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hyland Mr. Hyland
Speaker.P: We must concentrate our efforts on the productive areas of the economy. If we succeed in expanding our industrial base we will get over the first hurdle in rebuilding the economy. The Minister implies that that will be achieved following the establishment of the corporation, but I have serious reservations about that. The Minister's reference to the need to spread investment over a wide area pleased me. He said also it was his intention to give some priority to the development of our natural resources, an issue I have highlighted for some time.
